title: 111_s2851
content: The Act amends the 1986 Code and references sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It also includes a permanent extension and increase of the American Opportunity Tax Credit. The Act permanently extends and increases the American Opportunity Tax Credit by raising the credit amount to $2,000 and the limit to $4,000. It also extends the taxable years from 2 to 4 for various provisions related to the credit. The Act extends the American Opportunity Tax Credit, increasing the credit amount to $2,000 and the limit to $4,000. It also includes provisions for reducing the credit based on modified adjusted gross income. The Act extends the American Opportunity Tax Credit, increasing the credit amount to $2,000 and the limit to $4,000. The credit is reduced based on modified adjusted gross income. The dollar limitation on the amount of credit is adjusted. The text chunk discusses amendments to the Hope scholarship credit, including changes to the year references and dollar amounts under subsections (b)(1) and (d)(1). If amounts are not multiples of $100, they will be rounded down. The amendments to the Hope scholarship credit include adjustments to dollar amounts under subsection (d)(1), with rounding down to the nearest multiple of $1,000 if necessary. Additionally, a new provision limits the credit against alternative minimum tax for taxable years not subject to section 26(a)(2). The amendments to the Hope Scholarship Credit include adjustments to dollar amounts under subsection (d)(1) and a provision for limiting the credit against alternative minimum tax for taxable years not subject to section 26(a)(2). 40 percent of the credit allowed under subsection (a) attributable to the Hope Scholarship Credit is made refundable. The amendments to the Hope Scholarship Credit include adjustments to dollar amounts and limitations on the credit against alternative minimum tax. Various sections are amended by striking references to subsection (i) and inserting references to subsection (b). The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2010 and are subject to the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001. SEC. 3. Permanent extension of certain EGTRRA provisions related to education, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2009. SEC. 4. Permanent extension of deduction for certain expenses of elementary and secondary school teachers, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2009. SEC. 5. Permanent extension of qualified zone academy bonds. The amendment to section 54E(c) increases the amount to $700,000,000 for each calendar year after 2011. Additionally, there is a provision for inflation adjustment to increase the amount based on the cost-of-living adjustment for each calendar year after 2011. The amendment includes rounding increases to the nearest $1,000,000, exempts qualified zone academy bonds from certain rules, and changes effective dates to apply after December 31, 2010. The amendments made by subsection (d) apply to obligations issued after the enactment of this Act, with Davis-Bacon rules in effect after December 31, 2010. SEC. 6. PERMANENT EXTENSION OF SCHOOL CONSTRUCTION BONDS. Section 54F is amended to remove paragraph (3) and make adjustments for calendar years after 2009. The small issuer exception is extended to $15,000,000 and the egtrra sunset provision is eliminated. Additionally, credits under section 54F cannot be stripped. The amendments made by this section apply to obligations issued after December 31, 2010, and subsection (i) of section 54A does not apply to qualified school construction bonds. SEC. 7 of the text provides a permanent extension and modification of section 529 rules. It allows for changes in investment options under section 529 without affecting program requirements. The effective dates for these amendments are specified for taxable years after December 31, 2010, and 2009.
